data.stimulus:
Get Ready to Listen 

► In the first part of the lesson, we will focus on listening and vocabulary.

 

 

1. BloombergNEF is a leading provider of primary research on clean energy.

 

 

 

 

 

 

► Listen to its Chief Editor talking about the company and complete the summary.
data.template:
Bloomberg New Energy Finance (NEF) provides news, data and deep analysis on clean energy. Clean energy includes {{response}} and solar, small-hydro, marine, geothermal and other {{response}} technologies and energy efficiency.

They also look at the markets and predict {{response}}. NEF also collates energy data from projects all over the world; for example, 155 billion dollars were invested in {{response}} worldwide in 2008.

They study factors such as falls in gas prices and whether that deter people from investing in {{response}} energy, and the possible effect on coal and nuclear energy.

(write the exact words you hear and check your spelling carefully!)

options.label: Currently the most mature clean energy is wind power.
People know where to locate wind turbines.
Energy supply and storage are the most important issues.
Solar power will become the most viable alternative energy.
New Energy Finance studies the price of carbon in the future
When the technology falls in price, there will be a huge market for solar energy.

data.stimulus:
2. Now listen to the second part of the interview.

 

► Tick the FOUR points that are mentioned.

Let's review with some vocabulary...

THREE of the collocations below are correct and ONE is wrong.

 

 

Which words collocate with POWER?
► Tick three correct options.

Which words collocates with ENERGY?
► Tick three correct options

Which words collocates with EMISSIONS?
► Tick three correct options

Which words collocates with SUSTAINABLE?
► Tick three correct options

options.label: reduce carbon emissions worldwide by 2 per cent.
replace gas and oil with renewable energy.

data.stimulus:
Get Ready to Listen 

 

1. Listen to three lecturers talking about carbon emissions and clean energy.

 

 

► Choose the best ending for each of the sentences below.

 

According to the first lecturer, the world's governments should...

options.label: companies to reduce CO2 emissions by using alternative energy.
both industry and citizens to reduce their energy consumption.
companies to use alternative gases in their manufacturing processes.

data.stimulus: The second lecturer thinks it is up to business to encourage...

options.label: work much better than electric cars.
can already be seen on the roads.
are one example of fuel-cell technology.

data.stimulus: The third lecturer says that hydrogen-powered cars...

2. Listen to the same lecturers giving more opinions on the topic. 

 

 

► Choose the correct option from the drop down.
data.template:
• Lecturer 1 thinks {{response}} should make donations to offset their carbon emissions.
  • Lecturer 2 says paying a carbon tax would only work {{response}}.
  • Lecturer 3 insists that wealthier countries should stop {{response}} developing countries.
  • Lecturer 3 points out that many people in developing countries still don't have {{response}}.
  • Lecturer 2 wouldn't mind living near a wind farm because it would {{response}}.
  • Lecturer 3 says having wind turbines is better than living next to {{response}}.

data.stimulus:
In the second part of the lesson, you will focus on the case study of the company... 

 

► Read the company profile below and complete the information table.

 

Company Background

Fashion First is a leading fashion design company based in London. The headquarters and design studios span four buildings and comprise over 90,000 square metres of office space.
Fashion First is committed to improving energy efficiency and reducing its CO2, emissions as part of its sustainable business strategy. In addition to that, they want to create a reputation as a green company. Over the past five years, the company has invested half a million pounds in sustainable projects, which have resulted in £600,000 in savings, a total return on investment of 120%.
A recent downturn in business and rapidly escalating electricity and gas prices are forcing the company to find new ways to reduce energy costs, develop strategies to reduce energy bills in order to minimise the impact of price increases on its operations.
data.template:
{{response}}
London, United Kingdom
{{response}}
Four buildings, over 90,000 square miles
{{response}}
Reduce CO2 emissions as part of its sustainable business strategy.
Create a reputation as a green company.
{{response}}
£500k over the last five years
{{response}}
£600k
{{response}}
120%
{{response}}
Downturn in business
Fluctuating gas and electricity prices
{{response}}
Company wants to find new ways to reduce energy costs

 

NOTE: there are some extra options that you don't need

data.stimulus:
In order to reduce their energy consumption, the company needs to find out where energy is being spent.

► Here are some research findings:

  • {{response}} of all energy is spent on heating.
  • Cooling represents {{response}} of the energy spent.
  • {{response}} uses a quarter of all energy spent.
  • Cooking and ventilation use {{response}} amount of energy.

data.stimulus:
In the next live lesson, you will participate in a group discussion.

► It's important to use discussion language effectively to highlight your contributions.

 

Read the dialogue below. Four executives in an energy company are discussing what best source of clean energy is for their client. Complete the dialogue with discussion language from the drop down.
data.template:
David - OK everyone, {{response}}. Our client wants to start using a clean energy source to reduce energy costs and create a more sustainable image. Which kind of sustainable energy should they choose?

Julian - Well, there are several possibilities. {{response}} solar power? It's clean and cheap to run and it's very popular in America and in a lot of European countries.

David - {{response}} possibility. {{response}} Natasha? Would solar power be a good choice?

Natasha - Mmm, {{response}}. It's not always sunny in this country, is it? Not like in Spain for example.

Joy - {{response}}, the climate here may not be suitable to solar power. {{response}} wind power has a lot more potential, and wind turbines have a reputation of being reliable. There's also wave power but {{response}} it - it's very expensive to set up so {{response}} it would cost-effective. Julian, {{response}} this?

Julian - I {{response}} about wave power, {{response}} it's a good option. {{response}}, wind turbines would be perfect for our client. They would need some initial investment but it will really improve their image.

David - {{response}}. {{response}} get in touch with the CEO and see what she thinks? {{response}} that she will be happy with our recommendation.

data.stimulus:
Here is the discussion language you used in the exercise above.

► What do you use each of these phrases for? Drag and drop the headings into the table below.
data.template:
{{response}} {{response}}
  • OK, let's get started...
  • How about ...
  • Why don't we...?
{{response}} {{response}}
  • In my opinion, ...
  • I think that ...
  • I'm convinced that...
  • What do you think about...?
  • How do you feel about...?
{{response}} {{response}}
  • OK, that's a possibility.
  • That's true.
  • I agree with you 100%
  • That's a great point.
  • I'm not sure.
  • I don't know about it.
  • I don't think that's a good idea.
